docs.abstract: National Center for the Performing Arts, $400 million complex designed to be center of Chinese culture, opens in Beijing; promoters say lush, sophisticated and technically advanced center, which includes concert hall, opera house and theater, rivals any hall in Europe or US; center, designed by French architect Paul Andreu, has been beset by cost overruns, safety concerns and provocative aesthetics; photos (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS

docs.snippet: The National Center for the Performing Arts, a $400 million complex, has attracted at least as much attention for its cost overruns, safety concerns and provocative aesthetics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Compared variously to a floating pearl and a duck egg, the titanium-and-glass half-dome of the National Center for the Performing Arts formally opened its underwater entryway to Chinese officials and dignitaries here over the weekend. The $400 million complex, a concert hall, opera house and theater under one space age span, is designed to be the center of Chinese culture, just as Tiananmen Square next door was designated this country's political center.

docs.abstract: Tenth article in series, Choking on Growth, notes that every day, monitoring stations across Beijing measure air pollution to determine if skies above national capital can officially be designated blue; Beijing is preparing to play host to 2008 Olympic Games, and official Blue Sky ratings are city's own measuring stick for how well it is cleaning up its polluted air; recent pollution levels have far exceeded levels deemed safe by World Health Organization; Beijing's air is performance issue for world's Olympians; concern is that respiratory problems could impede athletic performance; pollution is inescapable health and quality-of-life issue for city's estimated 12 million residents; concern is whether city can clean itself up long after Games are over; graph; photos (M)

headline.main: Beijing's Olympic Quest: Turn Smoggy Sky Blue

docs.snippet: For the world’s Olympians, Beijing’s air is a performance issue. For the city’s estimated 12 million residents, pollution is an inescapable health and quality-of-life issue.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY; Zhang Jing, Ma Yi and Huang Yuanxi contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: Every day, monitoring stations across the city measure air pollution to determine if the skies above this national capital can officially be designated blue. It is not an act of whimsy: with Beijing preparing to play host to the 2008 Olympic Games, the official Blue Sky ratings are the city's own measuring stick for how well it is cleaning up its polluted air. Thursday did not bring good news. The gray, acrid skies rated an eye-reddening 421 on a scale of 500, with 500 being the worst. Friday rated 500. Both days far exceeded pollution levels deemed safe by the World Health Organization. In Beijing, officials warned residents to stay indoors until Saturday, but residents here are accustomed to breathing foul air. One man flew a kite in Tiananmen Square.
